annotations.note: All cultures should be regularly monitored for bacterial, mycoplasma and fungal contamination.
Perform quality-control experiments to verify patterning and specification by using qPCRs for brain region–specific genes.
Examine the experimental framework for modeling with organoids and assembloids that was outlined as part of a consensus effort27.
Validation of candidate genes from the KO screen involves generation of isogenic KO hiPS cell lines and their neural differentiation.

A practical CRISPR–Cas9–based strategy is used to generate a KO cell pool for validation, employing Synthego’s gene KO kit with three sgRNAs per candidate gene to induce concurrent double-strand breaks.
Nucleofection protocol is optimized for high-efficiency delivery of sgRNAs and Cas9 protein into hiPS cells to generate a cell pool with high proportion of KO cells.
The KO cell pool is used to validate specific phenotypes.

Successful execution of CRISPR screening in neural organoids and assembloids requires expertise in hiPS cell culture, differentiation into regionalized neural organoids, and integration into assembloids.
Expertise in lentiviral production and transduction, genetic engineering of hiPS cell lines (e.g., knock-in reporters or Cas9 expression), and large-scale pooled library delivery is required.
Downstream workflows require expertise in fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS).
Analysis involves extracting and processing genomic DNA from organoids, preparing samples for next-generation sequencing (NGS), and performing computational analyses to assess sgRNA enrichment.
The experiments using hiPS cells in this study were approved by the Stanford University School of Medicine Institutional Review Board and the Stem Cell Research Oversight.
Check cell lines regularly to ensure that they are authentic and are not infected with mycoplasma.
Lentivirus is often considered a biosafety level 2 or higher material and should be handled appropriately. Check the safety regulations in your institution.
